seg.seg: ... I will go quickly to Bādhari the Brahmin
I will quickly go to Bādhari the Brahmin. (41)
... (Paiṅgi)ka says: The houses of the teacher - may they be freed (?)
... says: You, noble one, go with the disciples to your own place; I, on my part
... Having said that, the noble Metrak left with his entourage. || Then Nirdhana
... says: Hello! Where is it that they give alms? || Then, seeing a man
... What are you saying? || Nirdhana says: This may be him. || The man says: Who? || Nirdhana says:
... Hello, you miserable one! Are you perhaps the sacrificial assistant? Don’t you know how to talk? || Nirdhana
Hey, miserable one! You must really be an idiot, [as] you do not even know [how] to say “sacrifical site”!
... if you are from the Madhyadeśa, you will indeed be without glory. Why that? || In the Samakkore [tune] || Surely you
If you are from Madhyadeśa, you will indeed be without glory. (41)
Certainly you must … ; you have (not) heard of [his] virtue, [and] you have no love for Maitreya, so that is not why you have come here. (cf 41)
... You have (not) heard of his virtue. You have no love for Metrak. Therefore you did not come here ...
... having come to see the noble Metrak. 1. || Nirdhana says: Whoever (to) Bādhari the Brahmin
... Hello, miserable one! You have lived in the forest of this land a life of endless misery
... you ... But for you there is still splendor since you went to that country where the noble Metrak
... sacrificial assistant ... the place. Whoever sees the pillar here, he ... the sacrifice
... on that very ground are the homes. All that this sacrificial assistant || In the Vañśa(vātra) [tune] ||
... properties they gave, they gave alms without greed, they gave to everyone
... today the sacrifice came to an end. 1. || Then here the gift ...

p.note: This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 11a (end)-11b (end). See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are basically adapted from 42.
Owing to the lack of Uyghur equivalent, this paragraph is not quite clear.
Nirdhane: cf. Skt. nirdhana- means “having no money”. In the Chinese version (Xian yu jing), he is called Lao-du-cha = Raudrākṣa. Vide 7-13.
kuciṃ is possibly in some way associated with kus.

aśśi talke māṃñe okāk träṅktsi mā kärsnāt: 100 has “do you perhaps not even know how to say «sacrificial assistant»?”; 38, quoting this as “do you perhaps not even know how to say «sacrificial place»?”, would place aśśi with the preceding clause, to give “you must be an idiot, [as] you do not even know [how] to say «sacrificial site»!” (with ref. to , ).
Since TA parno means “glorious”, one should associate parnäkk probably with paräṃ “glory”.
Owing to the lack of an Uyghur parallel version, the meaning of the following paragraph is not quite clear.
On kārāś, see 90: “cf. khotan. kāraśśa “Schlinggewächs”, “Wald”.” ānāntāp-ā is a new form, probably perlative singular. It looks like a loanword from Skt.: ananta+tapa- or anantava(t).
talke māññe säs: cf. line a7: talke māññe okāk.
vañśavātraṃ: name of a tune, so to be restored, cf. vaṃśavātraṃ: b2, : a3; stanza of 4 x 17 (5/7/5) syllables.

a7. kuciṃ is possibly in some way associated with kus.

a8. Since TA parno means “glorious”, one should associate parnäkk probably with paräṃ “glory”.

a1. Owing to the lack of Uyghur equivalent, this paragraph is not quite clear.

a4. Nirdhane: cf. Skt. nirdhana- means “having no money”. In the Chinese version (Xian yu jing), he is called Lao-du-cha = Raudrākṣa. Vide [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 7-13.

a7. aśśi talke māṃñe okāk träṅktsi mā kärsnāt: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 100 has “do you perhaps not even know how to say «sacrificial assistant»?”; [[Peyrot 2011]]: 38, quoting this as “do you perhaps not even know how to say «sacrificial place»?”, would place aśśi with the preceding clause, to give “you must be an idiot, [as] you do not even know [how] to say «sacrificial site»!” (with ref. to [[Schmidt KT 1999]], [[Pinault 2002]]).

a8. samakkorenaṃ: stanza of 20 (5/5/5/5) + 22 (8/7/7) + 10 (5/5) + 15 (8/7) syllables.

b1. Owing to the lack of an Uyghur parallel version, the meaning of the following paragraph is not quite clear.

b6. talke māññe säs: cf. line a7: talke māññe okāk.

b6-7. vañśavātraṃ: name of a tune, so to be restored, cf. vaṃśavātraṃ [[A 148]]: b2, [[A 187]]: a3; stanza of 4 x 17 (5/7/5) syllables.

b8. (ā)r(ś)o: cf. [[Schmidt KT 1999b]]: 282.
